questions.text: In which condition is La belle indifference observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Conversion disorder

La belle indifférence (“beautiful indifference”) is observed in conversion disorder.

  • It refers to a patient's indifferent attitude toward severe symptoms (absence of psychological distress despite serious medical illness or symptoms).
  • It is most commonly associated with conversion disorder (CD) or functional neurologic symptom disorder (FNSD) in DSM-5, though it can also occur in seriously ill patients with a stoic attitude.
  • It is characterised by neurological deficits without medical or neurological etiology, incompatible with known disorders.
  • For instance, the girl who is not able to see may be sitting very calmly.

Panic disorder (Option B) is characterised by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden episodes of intense fear or discomfort accompanied by physical symptoms such as palpitations, sweating, trembling, and feelings of impending doom or losing control. Individuals with panic disorder typically experience significant distress and anxiety during panic attacks, which is contrary to the indifference seen in La Belle indifference.

Schizophrenia (Option C) is a chronic mental disorder that involves a range of symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, disorganised thinking, and emotional dysregulation. Individuals with schizophrenia usually experience distress and impairment due to their symptoms and are unlikely to exhibit the characteristic indifference associated with la belle indifférence.

Depression (Option D) is a mood disorder characterised by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure, and other symptoms such as changes in appetite, sleep disturbances, and thoughts of death or suicide. Individuals with depression typically experience emotional distress and are unlikely to display the indifference associated with la belle indifférence.

questions.text: What deficiency is responsible for cognitive impairment in the elderly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vitamin B12

Vitamin B12 Deficiency is a common cause of cognitive impairment in the elderly. It can lead to memory loss, confusion, and even dementia if untreated. The deficiency affects myelin synthesis, causing demyelination and neuronal dysfunction.

Vitamin C (Option A): Its deficiency causes scurvy, presenting with symptoms like bleeding gums and weakness, but it is not linked to cognitive impairment.

Vitamin B6 (Option C): While deficiency can cause irritability, depression, and confusion, it is less commonly associated with significant cognitive impairment in the elderly.

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option D): Deficiency leads to Wernicke’s encephalopathy and Korsakoff’s syndrome, but these are less common causes of cognitive impairment in the general elderly population compared to B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Frontal

Explanation:

  • Based on the given history of patients, behaviour, such as urinating in public without remorse and difficulty in getting motivated, are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

A damaged part of the brain

Description

Frontal lobe

  • It plays a crucial role in executive functions, which include decision-making, motivation, impulse control, emotional regulation, and social behaviour.
  • Dysfunction or lesions in the frontal lobe can lead to changes in behaviour, impulsivity, disinhibition, impaired judgment, and difficulties in motivation.

Parietal lobe
  • It is primarily involved in processing sensory information and spatial awareness.
  • It plays a role in integrating sensory input, perception of touch, spatial orientation, and body awareness.

Occipital lobe
  • It is primarily responsible for processing visual information.
  • It is involved in visual perception, object recognition, and visual memory.

Temporal lobe
  • It involves various functions: memory, language processing, auditory perception, and emotional regulation.

questions.text: What are the distinguishing characteristics between delirium and dementia in Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

Explanation:

  • Delirium is characterised by a sudden and acute onset, often occurring over a short period of hours to days.
  • The definition of delirium is an acute decline in both the level of consciousness and cognition with particular impairment in attention.
  • This is not the case with dementia, which develops gradually over months to years.

Distinguishing characteristics of Delirium and Dementia

Feature

Delirium

Dementia

Onset

Acute (hours to days)

Insidious, progressive (months to years)

Duration

Short-term (hours to weeks)

Long-term (months to years)

Course

Fluctuating, worse at night (sundowning)

Steady, progressive deterioration

Consciousness

Impaired, fluctuating levels of alertness

Clear until late stages

Attention

Markedly impaired

Normal until later stages

Memory Impairment

(Option C ruled out)

Short-term memory is severely impaired

Short-term memory loss in the early stages, long-term memory affected later

Hallucinations/Delusions

Common, often visual or tactile

Uncommon in early stages, it may occur in advanced stages

(Option C ruled out)

Sleep-Wake Cycle

Disrupted (e.g., insomnia, daytime drowsiness, reversal of sleep cycle)

Sleep disturbances occur late in the disease

EEG Findings

Abnormal, showing diffuse slowing

Normal in early stages; slowing in late stages


Acuity of onset and agitation (Option A): While agitation can occur in delirium and dementia, the key distinguishing feature is the onset. Delirium involves a rapid onset of agitation, confusion, and fluctuating attention, whereas agitation in dementia is usually seen in later stages.

Agitation and irritation (Option D) are also present in delirium and dementia; hence, they are not the primary distinguishing features.

questions.text: A concerned grandmother brings an 18-year-old boy to you, reporting that he had multiple episodes of body jerking the day before his final exam. There were no signs of confusion or tongue biting after the episodes, and his medical tests came back normal. Which of the following conditions should be taken into consideration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Malingering

Explanation:

  • The boy's symptoms, which only occurred the day before his final exam, suggest malingering. He is likely faking his symptoms to avoid taking the exam.
  • Malingering is the falsification or profound exaggeration of illness (physical or mental) to gain external benefits such as avoiding work or responsibility, seeking drugs, avoiding trial (law), seeking attention, avoiding military services, taking leave from school, and taking paid leave from a job, among others.
  • It is not a psychiatric illness. Malingering is associated with an antisocial personality disorder and histrionic personality trait.

Incorrect Options:

Factitious disorder (Option B): In this condition, a person deliberately causes or feigns symptoms to assume the sick role. Dissimilar to malingering, individuals with factitious turmoil have no outer inspiration for their way of behaving. They might do it for the consideration, the compassion, or the sensation of being really focused.

Somatization syndrome (Option C): Individuals with somatization syndrome experience various physical symptoms unrelated to any medical condition. In somatic symptom disorder (SSD), exaggerated anxiety about these symptoms leads to intense thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, often impairing daily activities.

Hypochondriasis (Option D): Illness anxiety disorder, also known as hypochondriasis or health anxiety, involves excessive worry about illness, often without physical symptoms. Individuals may interpret normal sensations or minor symptoms as signs of a severe illness, even when thorough medical evaluations reveal no serious condition. This anxiety, rather than the symptoms themselves, causes significant distress and disrupts daily life.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a unique psychological phenomenon in which they believe that a close family member has been replaced by an imposter with an uncanny resemblance. This is commonly seen in which type of dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lewy body dementia:

  • Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in Lewy body dementia.
  • Lewy body dementia is characterized by cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations and parkinsonism symptoms.
  • Capgras syndrome involves a delusion that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect because Capgras syndrome is not associated with option A, C and D

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Delirium: 

  • Confusion Assessment Test (CAM) is primarily used for the assessment and diagnosis of delirium. Delirium is a state of acute confusion and changes in cognition that often occurs in older adults, particularly those who are hospitalized or have underlying medical conditions. The CAM is a validated screening tool that helps healthcare professionals identify the presence of delirium and distinguish it from other cognitive disorders or psychiatric conditions.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dementia: While both delirium and dementia involve changes in cognition, they are distinct conditions. Dementia is a chronic and progressive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, and reasoning skills. The CAM is not typically used for diagnosing dementia.

Option C - Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a psychiatric disorder characterized by disturbances in perception, thought processes, and emotions. It does not typically present with acute confusion or cognitive impairment, which are hallmarks of delirium. The CAM is not used for assessing schizophrenia.

Option D - Depression: Depression is a mood disorder that primarily affects a person's emotional state, such as persistent sadness, loss of interest, and changes in appetite or sleep patterns. While depression can sometimes lead to cognitive impairments, the CAM is not specifically designed for assessing depression or its cognitive symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics provides stronger evidence in support of delirium?

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fluctuating course:

  • Fluctuating course is a hallmark feature of delirium.
  • It refers to changes in the intensity and severity of symptoms, including attention, cognition, and consciousness, that can vary throughout the day.
  • Delirium is characterized by an altered state of consciousness that fluctuates, with periods of lucidity and confusion.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Occurs gradually over a period of time: Delirium typically has an acute onset, meaning it develops rapidly, often within hours or days, rather than occurring gradually over a period of time. This symptom is more consistent with a chronic cognitive disorder rather than delirium.

Option C - Preserved consciousness: Delirium is associated with an impaired level of consciousness. However, it is important to note that consciousness in delirium can vary, ranging from hyperactive (agitated and restless) to hypoactive (lethargic and withdrawn). While consciousness is impaired, it is not preserved, making this option incorrect.

Option D - Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: Delirium is more commonly associated with perceptual disturbances, such as visual hallucinations or illusions.

questions.text: What is the purpose of utilizing the confusion assessment test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Delirium:

  • Delirium is an acute state of confusion and cognitive impairment that often occurs due to underlying medical conditions or medication side effects. The CAT is commonly used as a quick and reliable tool to assess for the presence of delirium. It helps identify cognitive deficits, attention disturbances, and other symptoms associated with delirium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dementia- Dementia is a chronic cognitive disorder characterized by progressive decline in memory, thinking, and behavior. The CAT is not specifically designed to assess dementia. Instead, there are other specific assessment tools, such as the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), that are commonly used to evaluate cognitive impairment in dementia.

Option B - Depression- Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest, and changes in appetite, sleep, and concentration. The CAT is not primarily used for assessing depression. Diagnostic criteria for depression involve a comprehensive evaluation of mood symptoms, psychological and physical symptoms, and impairment in functioning.

Option D - Schizophrenia- Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and impaired social functioning. The CAT is not specifically designed to assess schizophrenia. The diagnosis of schizophrenia involves a comprehensive evaluation of symptoms, duration, and functional impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nucleus of Meynert is not affected:

  • The nucleus of Meynert, also known as the basal nucleus of Meynert, is a group of neurons located in the basal forebrain that produces and releases the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
  • In Alzheimer's disease, there is a significant degeneration of the nucleus of Meynert, which contributes to the cholinergic dysfunction observed in the disease.
  • The loss of cholinergic neurons and acetylcholine depletion is associated with cognitive impairments.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are seen: One of the pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease is the presence of intracellular neurofibrillary tangles. These tangles are made up of abnormal tau protein that has accumulated inside neurons. Neurofibrillary tangles contribute to the disruption of neuronal function and eventual cell death.

Option B - Neuritic plaques made of beta-amyloid are found: Neuritic plaques, also known as senile plaques, are another characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease. These plaques consist of aggregates of beta-amyloid protein that accumulate between neurons in the brain. The presence of neuritic plaques is associated with inflammation and neuronal damage.

Option D - Short-term memory is affected: Short-term memory impairment is a hallmark symptom of Alzheimer's disease. As the disease progresses, individuals may have difficulty retaining and recalling new information, experiencing deficits in short-term memory. This is often one of the initial cognitive symptoms noticed in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: What is the psychiatric disorder most frequently observed in patients with medical or surgical conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Delirium:

  • Delirium is a common psychiatric condition seen in medico-surgical patients. It is an acute and fluctuating disturbance of consciousness and cognitive function that often occurs in the context of a medical illness, surgery, or medication use. Delirium is characterized by a rapid onset and can cause impairments in attention, memory, perception, and other cognitive domains. It is commonly associated with underlying medical conditions, such as infections, metabolic imbalances, drug intoxication, or withdrawal. Delirium is considered a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation and treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Depression: While depression can occur in medico-surgical patients, it is not the most commonly seen psychiatric illness in this population. Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure, changes in appetite or sleep patterns, and other symptoms. While depression can be prevalent in various clinical settings, including medical and surgical patients, delirium is more frequently observed in this context.

Option B - Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by disturbances in perception, thinking, emotions, and behavior. It is typically diagnosed during early adulthood and often requires ongoing treatment and support. While schizophrenia can coexist with medical or surgical conditions, it is not the most commonly observed psychiatric illness in medico-surgical patients.

Option D - Dementia: Dementia is a chronic and progressive neurocognitive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, behavior, and the ability to perform daily activities. While dementia can be seen in medico-surgical patients, it is not the most commonly encountered psychiatric illness in this population. Delirium, with its acute onset and fluctuating course, is more frequently observed in the hospital setting compared to chronic conditions like dementia.
